lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/count.Count.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run count.Count.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
// Update the title above to match the actual product name
// Describe the count.action and its outcome.
// A description of the expected outcome goes here
* Count is a lightweight helper with an inbuilt to-do list
* @param filePath String filePath in which Count will read and save to
* start is a method that turns the Count program on,
* It calls ui.greet() and passes all commands typed to the parser
* If the command parsed returns a Deactivate object, Count turns off
* Parser contains methods which accept Strings to determine what action to take
* @param ls TaskList the Parser class receives to make changes to
* @param filePath String of the file path the Parser class will pass to create Save objects
* The parse method checks if the command parsed consists of single or multiple words
* If it has multiple words, it passes the whole command and the first word to multiWordParser
* Else it is a single word, it passes the whole command to singleWordParser
* @param commandFull This is the command parsed in by the user
public Action parse(String commandFull) throws CountException {
* singleWordParser parses a single word String ignoring case, returning an Action
* @return Action decided by the switch case
* @throws InvalidCommandException upon encountering an unsupported command
private Action singleWordParser(String command) throws InvalidCommandException {
* multiWordParser takes both the whole command and the first word, returning an Action.
* The variable rest refers to the whole command without the first word
* @param command This is the command parsed in by the user
* @param firstWord the first word in the command parameter
* @return Action decided by the switch case
* @throws CountException upon encountering invalid formatting for commands
private Action multiWordParser(String command, String firstWord) throws CountException {
return new AddTask(this.ls, new Deadline(commandSplitD[0], commandSplitD[1]));
return new AddTask(this.ls, new Event(commandSplitE[0], startEndTime[1], startEndTime[0]));
throw new IncorrectFormatException("Use a number after mark/unmark/delete to specify the task targeted!\n" +
throw new IncorrectFormatException("Invalid format for event or deadline!\n" +
* The Storage class deals with reading any existing Count.txt files for Tasks
protected DateTimeFormatter readerFormat = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("LLLL dd yyyy");
* @param filePath String filePath in which Storage will read from
* The load method checks if there is any Count.txt files in the specified file path
* It will then read the file and add the Tasks to an ArrayList to return.
* @return ArrayList<Task> with Tasks read from Count.txt
* @throws IncorrectFormatException if the String format of the read file does not match the format reader
* @throws FileNotFoundException if no Count.txt file can be found
public ArrayList<Task> load() throws IncorrectFormatException, FileNotFoundException {
throw new IncorrectFormatException("Incorrect format for Task completion scanned in Count.txt!");
throw new IncorrectFormatException("Incorrect format for Task types" +

throw new IncorrectFormatException("Incorrect format for Task description" +
* The TaskList class stores the ArrayList<Task>
* allowing it to be passed by reference
* Constructor for TaskList if no ArrayList<Task> is provided
* Constructor for TaskList if an ArrayList<Task> is provided
* The UI class formats how Count replies
* The reply method prints the output between two horizontal lines
* @param output String passed in to be printed
* The greet method creates a new Greet object and runs it,
* printing the String returned like how Count would say it
* The farewell method creates a new Deactivate object and runs it,
* printing the String returned like how Count would say it
* The abstract Action class acts as a blueprint for all commands
* the run method will execute the action
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException for any child to throw children of CountException
public abstract String run() throws CountException;
* The AddTask class is used to add tasks to the TaskList
* @param ls TaskList to add the task into
* @param t Task to add into the TaskList
* The run method adds the object's Task to the object's TaskList
* @return String for Count's UI to print
return "Added the following task:\n" + this.task.toString() +"\nYou now have " + ls.getList().size() + " task(s) in your list";
* The Deactivate class is used to turn the Count program off
* The run method returns the String for Count's UI to print
* @return String for Count's UI to print
return "Bye. Hope to see you again soon!";
* The Delete class is used to add tasks to the TaskList
* @param ls TaskList to delete the task from
* @param index int index of the Task in TaskList to delete
* The run method deletes the Task with the index of index from TaskList
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException if the index selected is out of bounds for the TaskList
return "Got it, I have removed this task from the list:\n" + curr.toString() + "\nYou now have " + ls.getList().size() + " task(s) in your list";
throw new CountException("Invalid list index chosen! Choose a number from 1 to " + ls.getList().size() + "\nType 'help' to see correct formatting examples");
* The find class finds tasks that contain the key passed to it
* The run method finds all Tasks containing the given key
* appending it to the return String
* @return String for Count's UI to print
String ans = "Here are the matching tasks in your list\n";
* The Greet class is used to give a welcome message
* The run method returns the String for Count's UI to print
* @return String for Count's UI to print
return "Hello! I'm Count!\nWhat can I do for you?";
* The Greet class is used to give a message on how to format commands
* The run method returns the String for Count's UI to print
* @return String for Count's UI to print
return ("1.'hello': Prompts me for a greeting!\n Usecase: hello" +

"

3.'list': Lists all tasks added in the order that they were added in
 Usecase: list" +

"

4.'todo': Adds a count.task with no date or time attached
 Usecase: todo bake bread" +

"

5.'deadline': Adds a count.task with a date or time to complete by
 Usecase: deadline homework /by 20/03/2024" +

"

6.'event': Adds a count.task with from a date or time to another date or time
 Usecase: event project meeting /from 20/04/2025 /to 30/04/2025" +

"

7.'mark': Marks specified count.task as complete
 Usecase: mark 2" +

"

8.'unmark': Marks specified count.task as incomplete
 Usecase: unmark 1" +
* The Delete class is used to list all the Tasks in the TaskList
* The run method lists all the Tasks in the TaskList
* @return String for Count's UI to print
String ans = "Here are the tasks in your list:\n";
* The Mark class is used to mark the specified task as complete
* @param index int index of the Task in TaskList to mark as complete
* The run method mark the Task with the index of index as complete
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException if the index selected is out of bounds for the TaskList
return "Good job, I have marked this task as complete:\n" + ls.getList().get(this.index - 1).toString();
throw new CountException("Invalid list index chosen! Choose a number from 1 to " + ls.getList().size() + "\nType 'help' to see correct formatting examples");
* The Save class is used to save the current TaskList as Count.txt
* @param filePath String file path the Save class will save to
* The save method saves the TaskList as Count.txt, overwriting any existing Count.txt
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException if the file creation fails
return "Your list has been saved over at Count.txt";
* The Unmark class is used to mark the specified task as incomplete
* @param index int index of the Task in TaskList to mark as incomplete
* The run method mark the Task with the index of index as incomplete
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException if the index selected is out of bounds for the TaskList
return "No problem, I have marked this task as incomplete:\n" + ls.getList().get(this.index - 1).toString();
throw new CountException("Invalid list index chosen! Choose a number from 1 to " + ls.getList().size() + "\nType 'help' to see correct formatting examples");

* The Deadline class extends the Task class
* changing the String representation to include the [D] symbol
* includes a LocalDate to complete the task by

* @param endTime String description of endTime in the format of inputFormat
* @param description String description of the task
* @param completion Boolean whether the task is completed

* includes a LocalDate to complete the task by
* and a LocalDate which the task starts from

* @param completion Boolean whether the task is completed
